I'm sure there were a few fans of the original film that were longing for the sequel but, seriously, come on now, it's not like there was huge clamoring for a sequel to the first film.  A film that wasn't that good to begin with.  Perhaps I gave the first film a break because Kevin James has a likable enough personality that I thought that people might gravitate towards that even if the film wasn't good.  And, in fact, people did gravitate to that and the film was pretty damn successful considering its minuscule budget.  But, and this has been a little over half a decade now, Kevin James just isn't that good of a comedic actor.  It's not like he ever was, but people found him so likable that they were willing to overlook the fact that he's just not all that talented.  That's why both Paul Blart films, essentially, are just one big 'fatty fall down' joke after the other.  Some people, in defense of James and others like him, would make the argument of if you were to take this same film and show it in the 20s or 30s that James would be regarded as a genius.  And that just couldn't be further from the truth.  To be fair, I just don't know what would happen, but James relies on a lot of laziness whereas Buster Keaton or Charlie Chaplin relied on their physicality because of they fact they weren't able to use to dialogue to tell their stories.  Chaplin made the transition to the talkies smoother than Keaton did, but Chaplin still had a way at adding a lot of heart and personality to films that featured a lot of slapstick.  Keaton was better at creating over-the-top physical stunts that no A-list actor, in this day and age, would actually perform.  The point is, that Keaton and Chaplin were both incredibly creative and innovative for the style of comedy they presented.  Kevin James is just repeating what others have done prior to him without any of the heart or creativity.  Again, he's just falling down because, you know, fat people falling over is funny.  It really doesn't surprise me that Kevin James had a hand in writing this film.  This is like a collection of deleted scenes from the first film that they thought would be a good idea to make a full-length film out of.  There's no way that this isn't how this film came about.  How else do you come up with a sequel to a film that nobody, in their right mind, probably loved?  It's either that or Adam Sandler just wanted to give one of his buddies more work, considering that almost nobody outside of Sandler actually casts Kevin James in their films.  It's not that I want James to go away, it's just that I want a little more effort to be put into the films he's in, instead of relying on what's cheap and easy.  The film has a few laughs, like Blart and the villain going back and forth on how crazy they are.  It's not like I would call this a hilarious scene, but it produced some chuckles.  And that's literally all I can remember.  There's also one ridiculously bad fight scene, which is understandable, but it's really fucking bad even by the low standards one has when watching a film of this type.  I know earlier I mentioned writing, but that would be offensive to the actual screenwriters that actually put in an effort to create stories.  I'm sure they still have to structure the film, but let's be honest here, not much effort was actually put into the script and I will be damned if someone tells me otherwise.  If you couldn't tell, this film was absolutely dreadful.  One of the worst of the year.  Though I am unsure of whether it was any worse than Grandma's Boy.  I will say this, Grandma's Boy may have been absolutely fucking awful, but I think they at least made a conscious effort at making a cult film.  I thought it was horrible and terribly unfunny, but there was some semblance of effort.  I can't say the same about this film.  I guess, in a way, this would have to be worse than Grandma's Boy, because it relied on everything that people hate about these comedies.  It was lazy and it relied on tired cliches and stereotypes.  It goes without saying that this is one of the worst films of the year, so far.  And Joe Dirt 2, another film from Sandler's production company, comes out this weekend.  So Paul Blart 2 will have some company among the worst films of the year category. I can't believe I paid to watch this.  It was $1.50, sure, but I still paid money to see rent this.  Maybe I was kinda hoping it might provide some unintentional laughs, but there's not even that.  This is an awful movie from beginning to end and it does nothing to improve Kevin James' image of relying of shitty and lazy 'fatty fall down' comedy.  Absolutely dreadful and please trust me when I say that you should avoid this at all costs.  I think Observe and Report is still out there in a $5 Walmart DVD bin somewhere.  That movie's strangely dark, but it's still vastly superior to both Blart films.  This, on the other hand, is fucking awful.

I LOVE Las Vegas! After multiple trips there, I'll watch any movie or TV show that features that beautiful and fun city. Unfortunately, that doesn't always work out for me. For every "The Hangover", there's something like "The Incredible Burt Wonderstone". So, when I saw the theatrical trailers for "Paul Blart: Mall Cop 2" (PG, 1:34), I said to myself, "Self? You know something? This one has potential." Paging Burt Wonderstone.

"Paul Blart: Mall Cop 2" is the sequel to the very profitable (read: low budget) "Paul Blart: Mall Cop" from 2009. Six years after thwarting a Black Friday heist at his local mall, and in spite of the original movie's tag line ("Security Never Takes a Holiday"), we now see Blart (Kevin James) and his daughter, Maya (Raini Rodriguez) on vacation in "Fabulous Las Vegas". Well, it's not completely a vacation. There's a security convention in town and Blart is hearing rumors he's going to be asked to be the convention's surprise guest speaker. And he's still the same old Blart - excessively proud of being a mall cop and insulted when someone doesn't give him his due, or give his job the respect that he feels it deserves.

During the back-and-forth over whether Blart is giving that speech, thieves begin stealing the hotel's art - and kidnaps Blart's daughter and the hotel valet (David Henrie) that she's been talking to. In the inevitable face-to-face showdown between Blart and Vincent (Neal McDonough),the thieves' leader, Vincent has his henchmen and Blart has his fellow security officers, each one more... unusual than the last. Throughout Blart's attempts to stop the bad guys, he proves as resourceful and physically resilient as he was in the first movie, as do his back-ups. But when the ways they battle for truth, justice and Steve Wynn's art reminded me of the scene in "Vegas Vacation" when Cousin Eddie takes Clark to a casino with silly simple, but impossible-to-win table games. But even "Pick a Number" or "Which Hand Is It In" were more amusing than this film's marble gun or goop sprayer.

One subplot in the movie has Blart dealing with his beloved daughter's rapidly approaching departure for college, which will leave Blart even more alone than you'd think based on how the last movie ended. There's a definite family-friendly vibe in the Paul Blart movies. The conflicts lack any real danger (unless you count the many assaults on Blart's person, mostly born of his own clumsiness). There's no real profanity and no sexual content, but also a plot, characters and dialog that are so bland that they make dry toast look like a fancy Vegas buffet. I enjoy family-friendly comedies as much as the next open-minded movie reviewer, but I do expect them to be funny.

This movie is earnest and tame, but just not that enjoyable. The script is lazy and settles for bon mots like "It's a bad day... to be a bad guy." James' delivery of supposedly comedic lines is so over-the-top that they're more likely to produce eye rolls than guffaws. He literally throws himself into the film's physical comedy, but the effect wears thin quickly. There are about four laugh-out-loud sight gags in the movie, but ONLY four - and they've probably already gotten their laughs out of you if you've seen a TV commercial or theatrical trailer for the movie. James' antics might give some kids a few giggles (very few), but there's not much here for adults to appreciate. Personally, I'd take James' work in his erstwhile TV series "The King of Queens" over most of his movie roles, including and especially this one.

This was the first film to receive Nevada's newly-enacted film tax credit. That's potentially a good news / bad news scenario. It'll probably mean more Sin City scenery splashed across the big screen... but that might mean I'll be subjecting myself to more cinematic suffering. Well, better me than you. After all, that's what our Facebook page is here for. So, instead of seeing this particular motion picture, I'd advise reading a nice family-friendly joke book... or taking a trip to your local mall. It's safe. "Paul Blart: Mall Cop 2" is fiction, grade "D" fiction.

The first Paul Blart movie was fairly inoffensive. Much like its titular hero, it was buffoonish and loud and something to simply shrug and ignore the idiocy. It had a couple funny moments tweaking action movie conventions, less so with Kevin James' numerous pratfalls. The world didn't need a sequel beyond the demands of the first one making money. And much like the Die Hard sequels, the "spiritual forbearer" of Blart, our security guard finds himself miraculously being put in the same miraculous position again, this time in a different location. While Die Hard 2 is a fairly mundane follow-up, Paul Blart: Mall Cop 2 is a true test of everything we hold sacred. Midway into the movie, I thought my review was just going to be my unintelligible suicide note.

Blart (James) is in Las Vegas for an annual security convention. He's brought along his teen daughter Maya (Rami Rodriguez) for some valuable father-daughter time, especially in light of Blart losing his wife and mother. It's at this convention where Blart runs across a team of art thieves lead by Vincent (Neal McDonough). It's up to the most unlikely mall security cop to save the day again, Vegas-style. Oh, and when traveling in Vegas, make sure to stay at the luxurious Wynn Casino and Hotel. Can I get a check too for the self-promotion like this movie?

Somewhere along the way, James and co-writer Nick Bakay decided the lovable lug needed to be a modern-day Pagliacci and be the crying clown America deserves. The opening act feels like notorious cinematic sadist Lars von Trier designed it. In the opening minutes, Blart's wife (Jayma Mayes) divorces him not even a full week into marriage. She couldn't stop vomiting from the thought of being married to him (this literally happens). His mother is run over and killed by a milk truck. His daughter has been accepted into college but fears telling her father this joyous news because she doesn't want to push him over the edge. This and he's still emasculated and looked down upon by an assortment of industry peers at the Vegas convention. All of this culminates in Blart becoming a paranoid, overbearing bully who loses the sense of likeability that comes naturally to James even in dreck. Take a moment where Blart intervenes with his drunken friend. The guy has been obnoxiously making sexual advances on a woman (played by Adam Sandler's wife) who just wants her privacy respected, and Blart saves the day by... convincing the woman that she should be flattered by the drunk's advances. Yeah. He rejects his daughter's academic accomplishment and demands she attend a lesser school closer to home for his own selfish benefit. He's pushing her away. Then there's the weird ongoing joke about his arrogant assumption that an attractive hotel employee is hitting on him; he's dismissive of her throughout and, here's the weird part, it ends up working. She falls for him ("I can't say no to you"). That's right folks, Paul Blart successfully "negged" himself a date. He's not a loveable loser any more. He's just an angry, bullying, self-pitying loser. 

There won't be a joke (I'll be charitable and refer to the as "jokes") that you won't see coming a mile away and still roll your eyes when they arrive. When the movie has an exotic bird walk out, you know it's only a matter of seconds before it comically engages in a fight with Blart. When he steps back onto the familiar confines of a Segwey, you know it's only a matter of seconds before he does something stupid. The crux of the humor of this movie is about 90 minutes of a fat guy falling down, and it still takes 47 minutes for the plot to get in gear. Let me repeat that for those in the cheap seats: a movie that is built upon the frail premise of being a Die Hard parody takes 47 unholy minutes to actually have its plot kick into gear. I watched Blart fight a stupid bird before the movie had the villain's scheme play out. Naturally, the film would have been bereft without that man-on-bird action (sorry to disappoint those who came here vis-à-vis a salacious SEO keyword search). Likewise we needed 28 shots of James falling over. Anything less would have been unacceptable to the viewing public. If you're going to be a dumb comedy just be a dumb comedy and don't waste my time. 

And oh what a dumb comedy it is. The first Blart film wasn't going to be confused with Tom Stoppard but it at least had some action conventions it could tweak. This go-round can't even manage that, and so we're inundated with tired slapstick and comedy that rarely rises above the most obvious joke at every opportunity. Blart gets ready to attack an intruder and, wouldn't you know it, he ends up punching an old lady. Hilarious. Even funnier is that the injured hospitality worker apologizes to her attacker. There's also a thinly disguised gay panic joke where Blart freaks out when a guy eats a brown banana. Who cares about how brown a banana is? At one point Blart hides inside a suitcase positioned at the top of the stairs. Why? Well so that the suitcase can fall down those stairs and hit the bad guy in the head. Don't you get it? He's fat. There are few comic setups or developments, no payoffs. Scenarios that should be comic, like Blart stumbling on stage of a Vegas dance show, are practically played straight, with the visual of Blart cavorting his large torso as the only joke itself. In case you forgot, he's fat.

I should not have been expecting much from Paul Blart 2 simply by the choice of jokes highlighted in the trailer. If you wanted a cursory reminder, it included Blart fighting a bird, Blart punching an old lady, Blart running into a plate glass window, and Blart getting kicked by a horse in what should be a spine-obliterating accident. Let's take this last gag and really explore how it's indicative of Paul Blart 2. The foundation is a dumb act of slapstick, but that's not good enough and so it's exaggerated to even dumber magnitude. With the help of self-loathing CGI artists (they can't all be Jurassic World), Blart ricochets across a street and violently bounces against a car door. It's not enough that a horse kicks this guy; he has to get kicked by a super horse because it just wasn't funny enough. That sums up the comic ethic of Paul Blart 2: when stupid isn't enough, amp it further, and then be proud about what you've done. 

Nate's Grade: D

Paul Blart: Mall Cop 2 should satisfy audiences looking for a safe, easy, no-thinking-required Comedy that's fit for the entire family. James, at least, seems like he was born to play the part. He does it well, even if what he does doesn't stretch him, or the material, very far. There's a fair bit of potential left in the tank if the filmmakers are willing to put in some effort instead of just recreating the first movie in a different environment. If there is a third, it will hopefully do something fresh.

You won't find much offensive in Kevin James's slick, innocuous vehicle Paul Blart: Mall Cop 2. You won't find much prompting an emotional reaction in general, so familiar are the jokes and situations. To his credit, director Andy Fickman ("The Game Plan," "Parental Guidance") keeps the inanity moving apace and there are a few chuckles to be had courtesy of the supporting cast. But, as is so often the case with big, star-driven studio laffers, "Cop 2" needed several more spins in the comedy punch-up machine before cameras rolled. In the past, James at least had likability on his side. He was a big, lumbering oaf, the ideal drinking buddy. But there's an arrogance to the way he treats people here, particularly a gorgeous hotel employee he's convinced is in love with him, that renders him strangely unsympathetic. Sequels are cynical by nature, but this one, with its casino product placement ad and director Andy Fickman apparently checking his text messages instead of trying to punch the limp gags into shape, is purely a paycheck. James may not deserve better, but the kids they're pitching this to do. Is it never funny? No, it's not never funny. It's just not funny nearly often enough. Far from the worst movie that you'll ever see, but you might leave wondering why you, the people on the screen, or anyone else in the theater even bothered.

There are good sequels, then there are bad ones. Unfortunately we get another one with Happy Madison Studios making the not-so-likable character Paul Blart in his sequel "Mall Cop 2".   Kevin James plays in the title role yet again as one of  New Jersey's well known mall cops this time he is more annoying and obnoxious than ever. I don't think I have sat through a movie looking at a character more annoying than any of the other bad characters I have seen in other bad movies. Actor Kevin James has spoken out about liking this character (for whatever reason) and had the idea of making a sequel. 

The movie begins with Paul Blart, who had just got married and started to have a new life; that is until his wife divorces him after six days of marriage. This is ridiculous as it sounds but it gets more distressing after only five minutes in. Paul's mother goes out for a newspaper, and then is randomly run over by a milk truck. It suddenly goes from sad to dark just minutes apart. After Paul's mother randomly dies. his daughter gets accepted into UCLA, but she does not want to tell her father because she thinks it will hurt his feelings. They then take a trip to Las Vegas, Nevada to go on vacation. 

Then the problems go on from there. There are so many gags and offensive jokes through out the entire movie. For example, the Segway that Paul shows off to two lousy men later in the movie is only there to extend the movie's duration time in order to get to the ninety minute mark. There are countless amount of these scenes in the movie that it makes the film boring instead of reaching its goal to be funny. 

Speaking of which, where is the comedy in this movie? None of the jokes are original and don't make any sense. I waited patiently for ninety minutes waiting for a funny moment to happen, but it never came. There are times where the movie adds in a random scene to make the movie look more ridiculous and redundant. There is one particular scene where Paul Blart attacks an African Crane, this scene tries to make Paul look like a funny guy, but really, he is being a jerk and shows that he is very easy to annoy. 

This isn't Happy Madison Studios' first film to have a sequel worse than its predecessor, Grown Ups 2, Joe Dirt 2 are both examples of bad films that the Studio should listen to the criticism in order to make their film better.

Blart-ing out any trace of entertainment value, this unwanted, unnecessary, and undesirable comedy cop-out mauls any laughs thanks to recycled material so juvenile that the Disney Channel would reject it for airtime. Loud, broad, and god-awful, Paul Blart: Mall Cop 2 plays out like a bad kid's movie mistakenly marketed to adults. An incompetent, he pratfalls about while facing basic challenges. An annoyance, he embarrasses his daughter while being overbearing. An unfortunate, he stumbles into victory purely by accident. An irritant, he gets rendered unlikable by putting him - and audiences - through the same sad paces as in the last go-roundwhich was pure garbage. The script renders him so incompetent, annoying, unfortunate, and irritating that moviegoers end up hating this ne'er-do-well--not sympathizing with him unfunny failure. A forced second helping of a cold dish that few people enjoyed to begin with, this sequel re-heats and adds more of the Z-grade shtick that made 2009s Paul Blart: Mall Cop so utterly painful to watch.

In this PG-rated comedy, mall cop Paul Blart (James) heads to Las Vegas for a Security Guard Expo with his teenage daughter (Rodriguez), only to discover a heist that hes intent on foiling. 

A poor man's Chris Farley, Kevin James fills the fat funny man vacancy in Adam Sandler's stable of stars. A frequent Sand-man collaborator, this former star of CBS's King of Queens realized this lovable lunk role again (I Now Pronounce You Chuck and Larry) and again (The Zookeeper). In fact, with Grown Ups, which was filled with just about ONLY ex-SNL castmates (Sandler, Chris Rock, David Spade, Chris Nealon), he took on a role that would've been Farley's for the taking had he lived (unlike James, Farley was an SNL cast member from the same period as the aforementioned). The difference? Farley killed both slapstick and cerebral comic patter. James nails only the former...and barely. Relegated to PG-rated buffoonish clowning thats not entertaining to neither children NOR adults, his Paul Blart: Mall Cop is an unfunny failure as both a character and as a comedy.

From the people that gave us the first Paul Blart film gives us a second with the plainly titled Paul Blart Mall Cop 2, a movie that is here and I honestly have no idea why. The first film wasn't a good film as it was just a very kid freindly version of Die Hard and while it's appeal was limited there was a level of heart that came with it. This second movie falls into the same situation but it still falls short of even the first film's low standards. The story this time revolves around Paul Blart going to Las Vegas for a security convention but a villainous thief tries to steal all of the hotel's art and it is up to Paul Blart to save the day. I am not exaggerating any of this, that is actually the story. The film obviously struggles from the very beginning but let's talk about the very few thing's that work here. The main thing that works in the film is actually Kevin James in the title role. James does deliver a very heartfelt performance and actually makes the movie a little bit more tolerable. Neil McDonough plays the villain and he gives it his all but the script is so bad it undermines everything. The script here is filled to the brim with jokes that aren't funny and throwaway characters that you will never remember after you see the movie. The comedy the script throws at us is mainly fat jokes. One or two would have been funny, but every scene has a fat joke and then they follow it up with a poor attempt at physical comedy. The best of these are actually seen in the trailer and even those aren't very appealing. Director Andy Fickman drops the ball here in more ways than agreeing to make this movie. His editing here is just shoddy to say the least and the use of CGI in some scenes is so obvious that the SyFy channel wouldn't even use it. To top it all off the ending of this film is just so cheesy you actually hate the film a bit more. Overall there is no use in dragging this review out longer than it has to be. Paul Blart Mall Cop 2 is just a extremely bad movie that we didn't even want to be made. James and McDonough try to make this work but this is just a terrible film that nothing could have saved it. Skip Paul Blart 2 and watch something else on Netflix instead.

As a whole this film fails at reaching the very low mark of its predecessor in almost every way possible. This Die Hard-inspired comedy "franchise" has now just added a very pointless sequel. 

Taking place in Las Vegas, Nevada, Paul Blart: Mall Cop 2 stars Kevin James as Paul--a bumbling mall cop who takes his job way too seriously. Now he's in Vegas for a security convention where he must stop a heist of the casino.

The entire film takes place within the confines of the Wynn Resort and Casino. There is no galavanting around the strip or hopping from casino to casino--so the should-be glamorous Vegas element is very glamourless.

As flippant as the first film is, this one adds insensitivity to the equation. The movie starts out by picking up where we left Blart last in his life--when he gets married. But we find out that his wife leaves him after 6 days. This is a character we really grow to like in the previous film and love the fact that she seems to adore Paul regardless of his clumsy ways. And then Paul's mom--whom he lives with--dies by getting run over by a milk truck. This is all supposed to be funny, but instead it's a jarring beginning for the few fans of the first film. 

Overall, it's much of the same criticisms from the its predecessor, except more. There are maybe 3 solid laughs in the whole movie--but the rest of the jokes fall flat and are yawn-worthy. However, those 3 laughs may be bigger than the biggest laughs from the first film. Although in the first film there were way more of them. In this one, the highlight may be the bird-attack scene--which is played off to its brightest potential and gets the biggest laugh. One of Paul's cohorts is a security guard named Khan (Shelly Desai) who had most of the other laughs, but was grossly underutilized in this movie.

At least, in the end, there is a redeeming value to all of this. But then again, we could've just watched the first film twice.

Paul Blart: Mall Cop 2
Initial Reaction: Now with a bigger selection of upscale stores

Main Characters
	Paul Blart: He's the mall cop played by Kevin James
	Maya Blart: She's Pauls daughter played by Raini Rodriguez

Plot Summary
	Paul is invited over to a convention in Las Vegas.  He arrives at the hotel and is ready for the meeting - only to find out his daughter is getting cozy with one of the hotel's younger employees.  This is something he tries to put a stop to.
	But while those odd things are going on, a group of thieves are trying to replace original artwork in several hotels and casinos with fakes.  The thieves intend to sell the original artwork for a lot of money.
	And you guess it - it's up to Paul Blart - along with several fellow mall cops - to stop the heists.

SCORING
Main Characters
	Paul Blart really gives it his all.  He's the one that drives the movie (as a comedy).  As for his daughter, she does have a few good moments, but she really doesn't shine as well as he does.  SCORE: 7

Supporting Cast
	The only member of the rest of the cast that's noteworthy is the worker in the hotel who slowly falls for Paul Blart.  
	However, the bad guys are really bland, and I felt like a lot of them were taken from you typical James Bond film (including their inability to hit where they are aiming.)  SCORE: 4

Plot
	The plot is okay, but there are far too many points where the characters overhear a critical piece of information (in other words, it's really contrived.)  SCORE: 4

Originality
	Paul Blart's giving it is all, but the rest of the film feels like your average heist film gone wrong.  SCORE: 4

Violence Factor
	One moment Paul Blart can't this a target from five feet away, and the next he's a perfect shot with that weapon (really).
	Besides, there are too many moments where the bad guys could've shot a good guy - and miss because they're such bad shots.  SCORE: 4

Other Moral Issues
	This film is supposed to be about how one average man can make a huge difference in the security business.  It's too bad the rest of the cast just don't hold up their end of the bargain.  SCORE: 4

Final Score (out of 60): 27			% Score: 45%

"Paul Blart: Mall Cop 2" is the sequel to the original film starring Kevin Smith as a mall security guard. In this sequel, Blart is invited as a distinguished guest to a conference of security officers in an upscale hotel in Las Vegas, Nevada and as chance would have it is the keynote speaker. In the background, a heist is being perpetrated by one of the hotel's guests to steal priceless art from its gallery and replace it with forgeries. Blart catches wind of this plot, and in John McClane style, takes down the villain's goons one-by-one, culminating in a zipline across the Las Vegas skyline. This movie has a 0% on rotten tomatoes from critic reviews. While I found the movie mostly dumb and inane, I certainly don't think it warrants a 0%. I at least found the movie passing, though admittedly not good. There are too many subplots in the movie, such as Blart's overprotective daddy issues and a family dynamic that feels out of place in a heist comedy. Smith does his best given the script, but it feels like he's there to be comic relief rather than a tangible, sympathetic lead. There were parts of the film I enjoyed, but some devolved into sheer idiocy. This is not a remarkable film but it has enough entertainment value to be a reasonable diversion from everyday life. Rather than spending full price in the theater, you may be better suited scoping this out on Red Box and having a nice laugh with the kids. I feel Kevin Smith deserves better than being typecasted as comic relief fodder ------------------------------------------------------------------ C

The bumbling mall cop Paul Blart goes to Las Vegas to receive an award for his "brave efforts" - his teenage daughter is once again kidnapped by a group of art thieves, posing as hotel employees. Blart attempts to thwart them, it works unrealistically, it goes along so predictably.
The overexaggeration of Blart falling, being hit or kicked by animals, and his especially dull group of fellow cops in town for a convention makes the movie so boring. What makes it especially boring is it's like an hour and a half long tourism ad for a Vegas hotel, Blart is only in a mall for around 4 minutes in the beginning, seeing the same interiors over and over gets so dull. Blart's fat jokes and awkward laughs fall short, he tries to prove himself to be more fatherly in the sequel, looking back at the first he was a cliched but likable character in some aspects. Here, he's such a painful "heroic" fat cop stereotype. Paul Blart rightfully earns the title of the worst movie in the past 5 years that I've seen, out of Sandler films and Parental Guidance, Blart conquers only in making viewers cringe.

In today's nonstop reporting of police brutality, we finally have a hero worthy of the modern mall cop. Yes, he's on vacation, but crime does not vacay. Only through PBMC2's fictional angle and slow motion camera work, and the everyman in the Midwest nature du humaine in Paul Blart, can we reach a state of heightened reality where people in our country can accept that mall cops put their lives on the line for the greater good of everyone.The black-and-white simplicity of the mission - move in, clear this, capture that, get out - become trampled into a morass of moral greyness. In that sense, Paul is a typical Eastwoodian hero: another lone gunman on a wild frontier, trying his best to square his actions with his code. Is he a cowboy, so addicted to his adrenaline rush that he's heedless of danger to himself and the men in his unit? Or is he, by virtue of his experience and talents simply better suited than a traditional policeman at estimating acceptable risk and getting the job done? PBMC2  doesn't engage the politics of war per se, but it blows a hole in the facile explanation offered by society that their concern is doing their job to the best of their ability and trying to make sure everyone gets home in one piece. In practice, nothing is that simple or clear-cut.

In early 2009, Kevin James starred in the family-friendly answer to Die Hard known as Paul Blart: Mall Cop! Set in a mall in New Jersey, the film was a major success hoovering about $146m in the U.S itself. Weirdly it has taken six years for the inevitable sequel to arrive. Frankly, I hated the the first installment, it was loud & overbearing, in other words just too Kevin James aka filled with just fat jokes! Another film that released the same here with a very similar concept Observe & Report (starring Seth Rogen) was a way better film in my opinion. However, after the genre trappings of the first film, it's only logical that the sequel turns out to be a family-friendly Die Hard 2. That is to say, it's basically the first one, all over again, in a different location and somehow better. The story follows six years after the event of the 1st film, as the over-zealous mall security guard Blart (Kevin James) is afraid that he has peaked personally - his wife (Jayma Mays) left him six days into the marriage & his mother (Shirley Knight) gets hit by a milk truck . An invite to a prestigious security convention in Las Vegas, all expenses paid, cheers him up a little, and he takes his long-suffering daughter Maya (Raini Rodriguez) along for the ride. However, dastardly high roller Vincent (Neal McDonough) is planning to put Vegas' world-famous security to the test by robbing the hotel where the convention is being held. Though racked by his own ego, Blart stumbles upon their plot and teams up with fellow convention delegates to save the day. Having started on awkward form, the film sets itself into old school physical humor, which Kevin James is actually good at -  Repeated auto-accidents, running into clear glass windows and getting beat up by a peacock are just par for the course. Aside from all the "fat man fall down" jokes that persist throughout James' filmography, the sequel also reprises the previous film's  running joke, about Blart's hypoglycemia. Yes, Paul Blart is an idiot. He's also gluttonous, clumsy, overbearing, self-deluded, and obnoxious. He's a veritable personification of the seven dullest sins, which the movie celebrates, inviting us to laugh at Blart as he stuffs his face, trips over things, and generally behaves like a buffoon. Blart is the protagonist as punching bag. No, wait, he's the protagonist as misunderstood everyman: Lonely. Hard-working. Just trying to do his best in an unfriendly world. All he does is to earn the love in order to avoid being lonely. Like from his daughter, Maya, who is willing to sacrifice everything for him and forgo acceptance at UCLA because she cannot bear to leave her childlike father alone. Like from the hotel manager (Daniella Alonso) and head of security (Eduardo Verástegui), whose rightful disdain for Blart as he blunders onto their turf and acts like an entitled moron will inevitably morph into literal adoration. If director Andy Fickman initially cannot decide if he wants us to laugh at Blart or cheer him on, he eventually comes down on the side of Blart Is Awesome! While the film may receive some harsh comments about the humor, I beg to say what do you expect from a film produced by Adam Sandler? It is going to find ways to make you laugh with its ridiculous gags, which may not be everyone's cup of tea! In the original 2009 film, Kevin James stepped out of Adam Sandler's shadow for the role of a lifetime, something which he is clearly good at! Neal McDonough as the film's villain has some funny moments as well! Especially his conversations with Blart on who is more crazier! James, who again co-writes the sequel with Nick Bakay, clearly has aimed at an audience even lower than producer Adam Sandler does in his own movies - the kids! On the whole, Paul Blart Mall Cop 2 may not be the best comedy out there, nor is it the worst! For people who enjoy physical comedies & don't mind films from Happy Madision (Adam Sandler films), will surely be entertained by this sequel, while the rest can avoid!

The first Paul Blart: Mall Cop was a pleasant surprise, it was an ode/homage to films like Die Hard. It had humour and heart, and solid acting all round. What it truly lacked was a villain.

So roll around the sequel, unfortunately what worked in the first Mall Cop is taken to the extreme and doesn't come off as charming as it did first time around.

The fact is this film is a mess in terms of storylines and at times appears it's an ode to Kevin James' ego which at times is jarring considering how much this sweet sensitive guy in the first one has become bigger bafoon than before. The rebellious daughter/overbearing father storyline is dragged to it's obvious conclusion.

The villains in this movie outwith the main two characters are just as interchangeable as they were in the first film. Though the plus side is Neal McDonough (TVs Justified Season 3) is particularly amusing when he gets flustered. Another storyline involves Danielle Alonso's hotel manager who on upon meeting Paul is told that she is attracted to Paul, and she is told this by Paul himself (ode to ego?) and by the end she is enamoured by Paul, which was a very cringeworthy storyline.

Now there are two genuinely hilarious scenes in this film, the first scene is when Blart comes face to face with some sort of bird (possibly an osterich) in the hotel greenery area as he and the bird duke it out, the bird gets some good pecks and kicks in which offers genuine hilarity. The second genuine scene which made me laugh out loud was when Neal McDonough's character and Kevin James' character come face to face in a hilarious dialogue scene where they try to say how crazy they are compared to each other.

Overall for me this film was a big disappointment, outwith those two scenes described above the laughs for the most part were cringeworthy, the story wasn't particularly engaging and it lacked the charm of the original. One to watch if you love Kevin James films otherwise you won't be missing anything special.

Paul Blart: Mall Cop 2 is an action comedy that is neither entertaining nor funny. There were not many expectations to be looking forward too, especially from the Happy Madison production company that Adam Sandler usually produces. Most of their films are going downhill with their lackluster comedy films. Mall Cop 2 is one of them; it carries the same humor that was in the 2009 predecessor. Yes, the first movie was fair and had some comical moments. The sequel is redoing the same humor, and it is rather eye rolling annoying than funny. Kevin James produces, wrote, and stars again in his film and the movie is filled with same repetitive fat jokes, redundant slapstick humor, and cringing bad one-liners.

 The plot takes place six years after the first movie; Paul Blart (Kevin James) is trying recover from some unexpected events. He goes on a trip with his daughter Maya (Raini Rodriguez) to a security officer convention in Las Vegas. Then, a gang lead by Vincent (Neal McDonough) is plotting to steal the artwork in that hotel. Paul has taken to his responsibility to stop them.


 The plot is ridiculous, and filled with the repetitive clichÃ (C)s that we all have seen before. Paul and Maya are now struggling with the father and daughter relationship, as Maya is growing up and trying to live a life of her own by making new friends and her protective father is restricting her. There are other characters that are also introduced in the movie, but are written one-dimensional which makes it forgettable. Paul Blart Mall Cop 2 is a horrible film; it does show Kevin James and his lack of creativity in bringing new humor to the sequel but ends up falling back to a repeat of the original movie.

"John Wick, shoot me now! "Paul Blart: Mall Cop 2" has stabbed film criticism in the heart"
Movie Review: Paul Blart: Mall Cop 2
Date Viewed: May 7 2015
Rating: Zero stars out of Five (No Half-star, it's really awful)
Directed By Andy Fickman (She's the Man, Parental Guidance, Race to Witch Mountain and You Again)
Written By Kevin James and Nick Bakay
Starring: Kevin James, Neal McDonough, Raini Rodriguez, David Henrie, Loni Love, 
Daniella Alonso, D.B. Woodside, Eduardo Verastegui, Gary Valentine, Vic Dibitetto, Nicholas Turturro, Ana Gasteyer, Geovanni Gopradi and Shirley Knight.

"Paul Blart: Mall Cop 2" has stabbed film criticism in the heart. It is soulless, lifeless, unfunny, putrid and worthless. It's one of the worst movies of this or any other year. Is this finally it for Kevin James? Has he run out of jokes? You're the King of Queens! You should know better. The only joke James can think of is the "fat man falling down" joke. He has repeated this joke to death. Apparently, James never met a "fat man falling down" joke he didn't like. Anyways, back to the larger point, why does "Paul Blart: Mall Cop 2" even exist? Why did it take James and Sony Pictures six years to make a sequel? Why should we even care about Paul Blart anyway? He's like Homer Simpson if he had hair, a badge and a police scooter. These two guys may not have a brain in their heads but Homer at least had memorable catchphrases and a decent job, Paul Blart is barely anything at all.

The first "Paul Blart" movie (which grossed an astonishing $186 million worldwide) was stupid and lazy but at least James was hard-working. Believe it or not the sequel is even worse than I thought it was going to be. There's barely a plot here, it's just Kevin James taking a nice vacation to Las Vegas and falling down over and over and over again. After the events of the first film, Paul (James) gets a notice in the mail saying his wife, Amy (Jayma Mays) has left him after just six days of marriage. To make matters worse for Blart, his mother (Shirley Knight) gets run over by a milk truck. Paul's long-suffering daughter, Maya (Raini Rodriguez) just got accepted to UCLA but she doesn't know how to tell her father because he is damaged and lonely. Paul also gets a letter in the mail, it's an invitation to go to a security officers convention in Las Vegas. WOW! Mr. James you won a free trip to Las Vegas! Did you win the trip by going on Wheel of Fortune or was it payed for by Columbia Pictures? 

Meanwhile, a group of art thieves led by Vincent (Neal McDonough) want to steal priceless paintings from the Wynn hotel. While his daughter hangs out with a young parking attendant (David Henrie), Paul is led to believe that he is the key note speaker of the security convention. When Maya gets kidnapped by Vincent, it is up to John McClane, I mean Paul Blart to save the day.
How did Paul Blart drained my soul away from my body? He has a fight with an angry peacock, he stumbles into a production of "Le Reve", the big Cirque du Soleli water show, he encounters a Mini KISS tribute band on an elevator, and he takes out the bad guys by shooting bean bags and marbles at them. Yes, ladies and gentlemen, the filmmakers are still mining this material as if "Home Alone" never happened. 

"Paul Blart: Mall Cop 2" is like a lot of other Happy Madison productions, it has weak slapstick, annoying characters, product placement, a fake heart at the end and it's essentially a vacation disguised as a movie. The direction by Andy Fickman (Parental Guidance, You Again and She's the Man) is so lazy, I'll bet he walked away from the camera to either play poker or hit the slot machines in a casino somewhere. The sequel was written by James and Nick Bakay (who is capable doing better work as well). 

Since he thought making "Paul Blart 2" was so much fun, James dragged genuinely funny people like Loni Love, Nicholas Turturro, former "SNL" cast member Ana Gasteyer and even his own brother, Gary Valentine into this mess as well. James has taken the word obnoxious to a whole new level because he transforms Paul Blart into a rude, self-absorbed, over-protective idiot of a father to his daughter. Naturally, his wild behavior makes the beautiful general manager of the hotel fall in love with him. Okay?... Why do you think Paul Blart is so attractive?

When you're watching an awful comedy like this, you expect to groan or roll your eyes but here, the jokes don't fly at all, James just assumes that these situations are going to be funny of themselves. Since the movie was mostly shot at the Wynn hotel, Steve Wynn has an awkward cameo at the end with a speech balloon on his head that reads: "Why did I contribute money to this piece of $&@?"
Several days after it was released, "Paul Blart: Mall Cop 2" scored a perfect 0% at Rotten Tomatoes but the rating was increased to just 6%. Let's just pretend that "Paul Blart 2" still has a 0% rating because the three critics who gave it a positive review are completely out of touch with the film world. Bruce Bennett, Jim Schembri and Simon Weaving should be ashamed of themselves for giving this awful movie a thumbs up. 

Among the jokes that don't work in this movie, when Blart is lying face-down on the floor, he crawls underneath a child's dripping ice cream cone just to increase his blood sugar and when Blart runs into a production assistant of "Le Reve", a disturbing scene happens, he eats a brown banana. Neal McDonough isn't given anything to do either, we learn that his character is allergic to oatmeal. Gee, I wonder what's going to happen to him at the end? When Blart finally encounters Vincent, they scream silly lines to each other. Here's one of them: "I will bring a folk guitar to a pumpkin fight, because that's how crazy I am!". Finally what is up with the young hotel valet who has all day to hang out with the daughter? Do you even work at the Wynn hotel? 

What happened to you Kevin James? You were a likable person, you were funny on TV and in "Hitch" but here you only managed to make "Zookeeper" look like "Boyhood". Placing itself as one of the worst sequels of all time, "Paul Blart: Mall Cop 2" officially marks the death of film criticism as we know it.

With Paul Blart: Mall Cop effectively getting worse with every year of age that passed me and Paul Blart: Mall Cop 2 being more critically panned than its predecessor, I felt like I needed to see just how low the film could sink.

To my surprise, Paul Blart: Mall Cop 2 was actually a significant improvement over its predecessor. That isn't necessarily the biggest piece of credibility due to the fact that Paul Blart: Mall Cop was simply dreadful.
The intro to Paul Blart: Mall Cop 2 is just dark. The titular character gets dumped by his wife six days into marriage, slapped by a child who won't hug him and then his mother is killed by a milk truck which is shown on screen. The humour is oddly dark for the mere intro to the film, and it doesn't precisely set the film up to be funny. If anything, I was laughing because the general idea of it all was just so stupid that I couldn't believe someone actually considered it a good idea. In actual fact, the level of ridiculousness in the film actually achieves humourous results because the entire thing is so damned stupid that the very idea of it actually being produced is able to create comedic results. Aside from the tedious character subplots, Paul Blart: Mall Cop 2 genuinely had a better story to it than its predecessor. Part of this is because Paul Blart: Mall Cop 2 at least has better villains. The first one had a bunch of MTV stunt performers pretending to be criminals, but Paul Blart: Mall Cop 2 attempts to be slightly more serious with the use of familiar yet more believable antagonists. The story is certainly far from ground breaking, but it at least puts more focus into delivering on its generic contract in terms of cheap gags and random sketches.
What Paul Blart: Mall Cop 2 calls character building is actually just an extended period of generic plot points which are short on genuine dramatic strength, rarely funny and rather familiar. But since the film paces itself more energetically, it doesn't focus on this too much. The budget of Paul Blart: Mall Cop 2 is a meager $4 million larger than its predecessor, yet the money is distributed more evenly this time around. Instead of the film relying too heavily on slow character building, the nature of everyone has already been established by the first film and this sequel just attempts to build off it. The budget is spent more on lively scenery and ridiculous stunts than anything, though the film manages to keep itself on a low budget the entire time. Admittedly, one of the negative results of this is the second-rate visual effects, but it is merely one of the flawed technical elements in a film which has a steady amount of colourful imagery. The change of setting is nice because the natural life of the hotel from all its glamourous lights to sparkling pools certainly lights up the screen, and it is all captured with nice cinematography.
Paul Blart: Mall Cop 2 is intended to be an action comedy like its predecessor, but due to a story that takes itself slightly more seriously than the significantly more childish nature of the first one, there is a greater use of action this time around. Spread out sensibly over the short 90 minute running time, the pace of the film is made better by a greater moderation between over the top stunt gags and other attempts at humour. Sometimes, the over the top energy of the film actually proves entertaining, and the fast pace of it all keeps some level of consistent movement going on, effectively ensuring that the film does not mess around with frustrating drama all that much. 
To put it simply, Paul Blart: Mall Cop 2 is obviously not a good film. It's story is generic, its humour is repetitive and there is a general feeling of predictability in it all. But thanks to a sporadic collection of unexpectedly over-the-top humour and an energetic effort from Kevin James, it isn't necessarily a boring one if viewed in the correct state of mind.
Though I expected Paul Blart: Mall Cop 2 to be unfunny, I did hold hopes that would find some level of enjoyment in the performance of Kevin James. And in all essence, I did. Kevin James' natural comedic energy makes him a genial presence in Paul Blart: Mall Cop 2, and it elevates the thin writing of the film to some mild extent of comic success. The fact that Kevin James takes the role so seriously is entertaining because he manages to actually take a stand as a legitimate action hero while also keeping it at such a level where it remains within the confines of a juvenile comedy. The man's insistence on injecting all his energy into the physical humour of the film is actually admirable on some level as the jokes are extremely repetitive, but the sight of Kevin James doing all his stunts is good for a sporadic laugh. Kevin James has a certain level of charm about him when it comes to line delivery and a massive load of physical energy which he empties into Paul Blart: Mall Cop 2 without remorse, so his leading effort should appeal to his fans on some level.
There aren't really any other cast members that end up making much of an impact though. I didn't really expect many to make much of a difference, but the presence of Gary Valentine was something I hoped would be bring more laughter into it. When there was ultimately nothing funny about him being in the film, I'll admit to being disappointed. 

So Paul Blart: Mall Cop 2 is precisely as ludicrous and derivative as you would expect, but its overtly ridiculous nature and the energetic leading effort of Kevin James manages to keep a sense of consistent energy in the sporadic laughs of the film.

There are good sequels, then there are bad ones. Unfortunately we get another one with Happy Madison Studios making the not-so-likable character Paul Blart in his sequel "Mall Cop 2".   Kevin James plays in the title role yet again as one ofThere are good sequels, then there are bad ones. Unfortunately we get another one with Happy Madison Studios making the not-so-likable character Paul Blart in his sequel "Mall Cop 2".   Kevin James plays in the title role yet again as one of  New Jersey's well known mall cops this time he is more annoying and obnoxious than ever. I don't think I have sat through a movie looking at a character more annoying than any of the other bad characters I have seen in other bad movies. Actor Kevin James has spoken out about liking this character (for whatever reason) and had the idea of making a sequel. The movie begins with Paul Blart, who had just got married and started to have a new life; that is until his wife divorces him after six days of marriage. This is ridiculous as it sounds but it gets more distressing after only five minutes in. Paul's mother goes out for a newspaper, and then is randomly run over by a milk truck. It suddenly goes from sad to dark just minutes apart. After Paul's mother randomly dies. his daughter gets accepted into UCLA, but she does not want to tell her father because she thinks it will hurt his feelings. They then take a trip to Las Vegas, Nevada to go on vacation. Then the problems go on from there. There are so many gags and offensive jokes through out the entire movie. For example, the Segway that Paul shows off to two lousy men later in the movie is only there to extend the movie's duration time in order to get to the ninety minute mark. There are countless amount of these scenes in the movie that it makes the film boring instead of reaching its goal to be funny. Speaking of which, where is the comedy in this movie? None of the jokes are original and don't make any sense. I waited patiently for ninety minutes waiting for a funny moment to happen, but it never came. There are times where the movie adds in a random scene to make the movie look more ridiculous and redundant. There is one particular scene where Paul Blart attacks an African Crane, this scene tries to make Paul look like a funny guy, but really, he is being a jerk and shows that he is very easy to annoy. This isn't Happy Madison Studios' first film to have a sequel worse than its predecessor, Grown Ups 2, Joe Dirt 2 are both examples of bad films that the Studio should listen to the criticism in order to make their film better. "Criticism is a lesson"- 30 Cents.

Want to scream bloody murder? Then the new Halloween is the trick-or-treat frightfest for you. But, first, a leap of faith is required. You have to forget that there are already nine sequels and remakes of John Carpenter’s 1978 original — thankfully, director David Gordon Green and coscreenwriters Danny McBride and Jeff Fradley pretend those lame copies never existed (no loss there). To them, Halloween 2018 is the first sequel ever to Carpenter’s horror classic. It’s been 40 years since babysitter Laurie Strode (Jamie Lee Curtis) got rocked by PTSD when the masked killer Michael Myers rampaged through the leafy streets of her hometown of Haddonfield, Illinois. And in the years since, the Final Girl has turned herself into Bloody Grandma, a rabid survivalist who’s booby-trapped her house and stayed rifle-ready until the day Michael — the essence of pure evil — breaks out of his loonybin and comes for her. That day is here. And, yup, it’s Halloween.Just watching Curtis dig into the role of this former-babysitter-turned-hardcore-avenger will keep you on the edge of your seat. She’s a marvel of ferocity and feeling. Laurie knows that her Michael obsession has lost her custody of her now-adult daughter Karen (Judy Greer), trained in combat since childhood, and caused a rift with her granddaughter Allyson (Andi Matichak). But she’ll live with it if her family can be safe. Playing the naïve Laurie made Curtis a star at 19; now she brings a sense of loss, regret and separation to the role that deepens the character’s humanity without diminishing her resolve. It’s a savage roar of a performance that stays alert to nuance. And it fits in perfectly with Green’s concept of the film as a feminist parable in which three women come together to call #TimesUp on a male predator.In other areas, the filmmaker must fight familiarity in a sometimes losing battle. Though he ups the violence quotient on Carpenter’s film, Green’s R-rated sequel comes after the torture-porn excess of the Saw and Hostel franchises that numbed us to gore. It also lacks the satiric bite of Get Out. This is a film made by Carpenter fans for other Carpenter fans. Green brought on the master, now 70, as advisor and to update his eerie synthesizer score with son Cody Carpenter and Daniel Davies. The credits ape the original’s right down to the serif font, and cinematographer Michael Simmonds indulges in those long, suspenseful tracking shots that take Myers’ point of view. The first actor to play the horror-flick icon, Nick Castle, joins forces with James Jude Courtney, to embody the older but still death-fixated man-in-the-mask. And yes, that William Shatner/Star Trek mask painted white is very much present and accounted for. So what’s new? Not much according to the plot, which more or less follows the same trajectory as the original. The first Halloween‘s Dr. Loomis, played by the late Donald Pleasance, has been replaced by the equally obsessive Dr. Sartain (Haluk Bilginer). The shrink wants to know why Michael kills. For a with-it touch, two Brit podcasters (Rhian Rees and Jefferson Hall) have been added to the equation to retell the homicidal maniac’s story for the uninitiated. They are also around to provide fresh meat before Michael goes into slaughter mode on the babysitter beat.All things end, as they must, with the Strode women taking on Michael in the woods. Halloween started as a slasher movie done with an inventive talent for the game by Carpenter. That Green’s sequel works as well as it does — it’s still a slasher movie — is due only in part to the director and his collaborators’ copycat admiration for Carpenter’s blueprint. Mostly it’s the troubled times we live in that allows this energizing, elemental horror film to touch a raw nerve for #MeToo. We watch a woman call a male monster to account for her own lasting trauma. That’s too real to laugh off as Hollywood make-believe. We’re living it.

rt_summary: Six years after he saved the day at his beloved New Jersey shopping mall, security guard Paul Blart (Kevin James) is taking a well-deserved vacation. In recognition for his hard work, he's won an all-expenses-paid trip to a security convention in Las Vegas, and decides to take his teenage daughter, Maya (Raini Rodriguez), with him. True to form, however, Paul just can't relax and take it easy, so when he uncovers a criminal threat to the hotel, he springs into action.
meta_summary: Security guard Paul Blart heads to Las Vegas to attend a Security Guard Expo with his teenage daughter Maya (Raini Rodriguez) before she departs for college. While at the convention, he inadvertently discovers a heist - and it's up to Blart to apprehend the criminals. [Sony Pictures]
